primary_deity.name: Lord Mahakaleshwar
primary_deity.meaning: The Great Lord of Time, the One Beyond Death

mythology.origin_story: When the demon Dushana threatened to destroy Ujjain and its devotees, King Chandrasena's intense prayer summoned Lord Shiva. The Lord manifested as a pillar of fierce light, destroyed the demon, and agreed to reside eternally as Mahakaleshwar—the conqueror of time and death, protector of the faithful.
mythology.cosmic_significance: Mahakal is the fierce form of Shiva who presides over time and death. Unlike other forms that promise boons within life, Mahakal offers liberation from the cycle of birth and death itself. His south-facing position symbolizes his supremacy over Yama (Death). Worshipping here is said to free devotees from the fear of mortality.

sacred_mantras.name: Mahakaleshwar Dhyana Mantra
sacred_mantras.meaning: Salutations to the Great Lord of Time
sacred_mantras.benefit: Grants victory over time, removes fear of death, and bestows spiritual liberation

sacred_mantras.name: Maha Mrityunjaya Mantra
sacred_mantras.sanskrit: ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे सुगन्धिं पुष्टिवर्धनम् उर्वारुकमिव बन्धनान्मृत्योर्मुक्षीय माऽमृतात्
sacred_mantras.meaning: We worship the three-eyed one who nourishes all beings. May we be liberated from death, as the cucumber is severed from bondage to the vine.
sacred_mantras.benefit: Protection from untimely death, healing of diseases, and liberation from the cycle of rebirth
